name: 1598_C. Delete Two Elements
description:
Monocarp has got an array a consisting of n integers. Let's denote k as the mathematic mean of these elements (note that it's possible that k is not an integer). 

The mathematic mean of an array of n elements is the sum of elements divided by the number of these elements (i. e. sum divided by n).

Monocarp wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mathematic mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still equal to k.

Your task is to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.

Monocarp has an array a with n integers. The mean k is calculated by dividing the sum of these elements by the number of elements (n). Monocarp wants to remove two elements from the array so that the mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still k. The task is to find the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (where i < j) where removing the elements at these positions will result in the mean of the remaining elements being equal to k. Be sure to consider all constraints and edge cases in your solution.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.
Write a main() function and use input() function to read input from stdin

Monocarp has an array a of n integers. The mean k is calculated as the sum of elements divided by the number of elements (sum/n). He wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still k. Calculate the number of pairs [i, j] (i < j) such that deleting the elements at these positions keeps the mean of (n - 2) elements equal to k.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.
Write a main() function and use input() function to read input from stdin
completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_pairs_to_delete(n, arr):
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean = total_sum / n
    count = 0
    
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            new_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
            new_count = n - 2
            new_mean = new_sum / new_count
            if new_mean == mean:
                count += 1
    
    return count

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(input())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the number of elements in the array
    n = int(input())
    # Read the array elements
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    # Calculate and print the result
    result = calculate_pairs_to_delete(n, arr)
    print(result)
from typing import List
from typing import List

def calculate_pairs(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean = total_sum / n
    
    count = 0
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            new_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
            new_mean = new_sum / (n - 2)
            if new_mean == mean:
                count += 1
    return count

# Provide the Interface
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = calculate_pairs(n, arr)
    print(result)
from typing import List
from typing import List

def find_pairs(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean = total_sum / n
    
    count = 0
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            if (total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]) / (n - 2) == mean:
                count += 1
    return count

# Interface
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = find_pairs(n, arr)
    print(result)
from typing import List
from typing import List

def find_pairs(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    # Calculate the mean of the array
    mean_value = sum(arr) / n
    
    # Initialize the count of valid pairs
    count = 0
    
    # Iterate through all possible pairs of indices [i, j] where i < j
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            # Create a new array excluding the elements at indices i and j
            new_arr = arr[:i] + arr[i+1:j] + arr[j+1:]
            
            # Calculate the mean of the new array
            new_mean = sum(new_arr) / (n - 2)
            
            # Check if the new mean is equal to the original mean
            if new_mean == mean_value:
                count += 1
    
    return count

# Provide the Interface
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = find_pairs(n, arr)
    print(result)
from typing import List
from typing import List

def find_pairs_to_remove(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean = total_sum / n
    
    count = 0
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            if i != j:
                new_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
                if new_sum / (n - 2) == mean:
                    count += 1
    return count

# Interface
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = find_pairs_to_remove(n, arr)
    print(result)

    total_sum = sum(arr)

        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            if (total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]) / (n - 2) == mean:

    return count

def calculate_pairs_to_maintain_mean(n: int, arr: list[int]) -> int:
    original_mean = sum(arr) / n
    count = 0

    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            new_arr = arr[:i] + arr[i + 1:j] + arr[j + 1:]
            if sum(new_arr) / (n - 2) == original_mean:
                count += 1

    return count

# Read input and process each test case

for _ in range(t):

    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))

## main.py
import sys

def calculate_pairs(n, arr):
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean = total_sum / n

    count = 0
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            new_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
            new_n = n - 2
            if new_sum / new_n == mean:
                count += 1
    return count

# Provide the Interface
t = int(input().strip())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input().strip())
    arr = list(map(int, input().strip().split()))

from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List

def calculate_pairs_to_maintain_mean(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    original_mean = sum(arr) / n
    count = 0
    pair_sums = {}

    # Calculate the sum of each subarray without the i-th and j-th elements
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            new_sum = sum(arr[:i]) + sum(arr[i+1:j]) + sum(arr[j+1:])
            new_length = n - 2
            new_mean = new_sum / new_length
            if new_mean == original_mean:
                pair = (i, j)
                if pair not in pair_sums:
                    pair_sums[pair] = True
                    count += 1

    return count

# Provide the Interface
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = calculate_pairs_to_maintain_mean(n, arr)
    print(result)
from typing import List
from typing import List

def find_pairs_to_delete(n: int, arr: List[int]) -> int:
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    mean = total_sum / n
    pairs_count = 0

    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            if i != j:
                new_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
                if new_sum / (n - 2) == mean:
                    pairs_count += 1

    return pairs_count

# Interface
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    result = find_pairs_to_delete(n, arr)
    print(result)
plans:
requirement analysis:
The problem requires calculating the number of pairs of positions [i, j] such that deleting the elements at these positions results in the mean of the remaining elements being the same as the original mean. This involves summing the elements, calculating the mean, and then checking pairs to see if their deletion maintains the mean. The constraints are high, requiring optimization for large inputs.
requirement pool:
- Implement a function to calculate the mean of the array.
- Create a function to iterate through pairs of indices and check if deleting the elements at these indices maintains the mean.
- Optimize the solution for large inputs to ensure it runs efficiently within the given constraints.
- Handle edge cases such as arrays with all identical elements and arrays with zero or one element.
To solve this problem efficiently, we will use Python's built-in functions and libraries to handle the array operations. The main challenge is to find pairs of indices that, when removed, do not change the mean of the remaining elements. We will calculate the mean of the array once and then iterate through pairs of indices to check if their deletion maintains the mean. The solution will be optimized to handle large inputs within the given constraints.

    'mathematical mean': the sum of all elements divided by the number of elements
    'pair of positions': two elements in the array that are selected together

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'exactly two elements': means we need to consider pairs of indices [i, j] where i < j

# [degree adverb] 
    'equal to': means the remaining elements after deletion should have the same mean as the original array

# [code logic]
    (check if there are steps should be considered simultaneously)

# [edge case] 
    n = 3, a = [1, 1, 1]
    explanation: There are no pairs [i, j] such that removing them changes the mean, so the output is 0.
    n = 4, a = [2, 2, 2, 2]
    explanation: Any pair of elements can be removed, and the mean will remain the same, so the output is 6.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We need extra code to handle the edge case where n = 3 and all elements are the same.

            return 3  # Any two elements can be removed, the mean remains the same

requirement analysis:
The problem requires calculating the number of pairs of positions to delete from an array such that the mean remains unchanged. This involves summing the elements, calculating the mean, and then finding pairs that, when removed, keep the mean the same. The constraints are high, with up to 2 * 10^5 elements and up to 10^4 test cases, so efficiency is crucial.
requirement pool:
- Implement a solution that calculates the mean and checks pairs efficiently
- Ensure the solution can handle large inputs without timing out
- Provide clear and accurate output for each test case
To solve this problem efficiently, we will use Python due to its powerful standard libraries and ability to handle large datasets. The approach involves calculating the mean of the array and then iterating through all possible pairs of indices to check if removing them keeps the mean unchanged. We will use a brute-force method initially to ensure correctness and then optimize if necessary.
Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
 # [core concept]
    'mathematical mean'
    In the requirement, it refers to the average of all elements in the array, calculated as the sum of elements divided by the number of elements.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    No phrase showing quantity relationship

# [degree adverb] 
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
    (check if there are steps should be considered simultaneously)
    The plan suggests using a brute-force approach initially to ensure correctness. Here's a detailed logic:
    1. Calculate the mean (k) of the entire array.
    2. Iterate through all possible pairs of indices (i, j) where i < j.
    3. For each pair, calculate the new mean after removing the elements at indices i and j.
    4. Check if the new mean equals k.
    5. Count all such pairs.

# [edge case] 
    Edge case 1: n = 3
    Input: [1, 2, 3]
    Explanation: Since there are only 3 elements, removing any two elements will leave only 1 element, which cannot be equal to the mean of the original array. Thus, the number of pairs is 0.
    Edge case 2: n = 4, array = [1, 2, 3, 6]
    Input: [1, 2, 3, 6]
    Explanation: The mean (k) is (1+2+3+6)/4 = 3. Removing the elements at indices 1 and 2 (values 2 and 3) leaves [1, 6], which has a mean of (1+6)/2 = 3.5, not equal to 3. Thus, the number of pairs is 0.
    Edge case 3: n = 5, array = [1, 3, 2, 3, 3]
    Input: [1, 3, 2, 3, 3]
    Explanation: The mean (k) is (1+3+2+3+3)/5 = 2.4. Removing the elements at indices 1 and 3 (values 3 and 2) leaves [1, 3, 3, 3], which has a mean of (1+3+3+3)/4 = 2.5, not equal to 2.4. Thus, the number of pairs is 0.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The brute-force approach will naturally handle these cases by not counting pairs that cannot be removed to maintain the mean.

    Edge case 2:

    Explanation: The mean of the array is (1+3+2+4)/4 = 2.5. The pairs [1, 2] and [2, 3] can be removed to keep the mean unchanged (mean of [1, 2, 4] and [3, 2, 4] is 2.5).
    Edge case 3:
    Input: n = 5, a = [1, 1, 1, 1, 1]
    Explanation: The mean of the array is (1+1+1+1+1)/5 = 1. Any two elements can be removed to keep the mean unchanged (mean of any three elements is 1).

 # [core concept]
    'mean': the average value of a set of numbers, calculated by dividing the sum of the numbers by the count of the numbers.
    Explanation: In this problem, we need to find pairs of indices [i, j] such that removing the elements at these positions keeps the mean of the remaining elements equal to the original mean.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'more than': means that the number of times a value appears in the array is greater than or equal to the value itself.
    Explanation: For example, if a number appears 3 times, it means it is more than 3.

# [degree adverb] 
    'largest': means the biggest number in the array.
    Explanation: We need to find the largest number to understand the range of values we are dealing with.

# [code logic]
    (check if there are steps should be considered simultaneously)
    To solve this problem, we will follow these steps:
    1. Calculate the mean of the array.
    2. Iterate through all possible pairs of indices [i, j] where i < j.
    3. For each pair, calculate the new mean of the remaining elements.
    4. Check if the new mean is equal to the original mean.
    5. Count the number of such pairs.

# [edge case] 
    search([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]) = 3
    Explanation: The original mean is (1+2+3+4+5+6+7)/7 = 4. Removing any two elements that are not the smallest and largest will result in a mean of 4. For example, removing elements at positions 1 and 2 (2 and 3) will result in a mean of 4.
    search([1, 1, 1, 1]) = 6
    Explanation: The original mean is (1+1+1+1)/4 = 1. Removing any two elements will result in a mean of 1. There are 6 possible pairs: [1,2], [1,3], [1,4], [2,3], [2,4], [3,4].

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge case. The provided logic will work for any array of positive integers.

 # [core concept]
    'mean': the average value of a set of numbers, calculated by dividing the sum of the numbers by the count of the numbers.
    Explanation: In this problem, we need to find pairs of indices [i, j] such that the mean of the remaining elements after removing the elements at these indices is the same as the original mean.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'divided by': used to indicate the division of one number by another.
    Explanation: In the requirement, the mean is calculated as the sum of elements divided by the number of elements (sum/n).

# [degree adverb] 
    'exactly': used to indicate a specific quantity or number.
    Explanation: The phrase "exactly two elements" specifies that we need to remove exactly two elements from the array.

# [code logic]
    To implement this, we need to:
    1. Calculate the original mean of the array.
    2. Iterate through all possible pairs of indices [i, j] where i < j.
    3. For each pair, calculate the new mean of the remaining elements after removing the elements at indices i and j.
    4. Count the number of pairs that result in the same mean as the original array.

# [edge case] 
    Edge case 1: n = 3, array = [1, 2, 3]
    Expected output: 0
    Explanation: With only three elements, it's impossible to remove two elements and still have the mean of the remaining elements equal to the original mean.

    Edge case 2: n = 4, array = [1, 2, 3, 6]
    Expected output: 1
    Explanation: The original mean is (1+2+3+6)/4 = 3. Removing the elements at indices 1 and 2 (values 2 and 3) results in a mean of (1+6)/2 = 3.5, which is not equal to the original mean.

    Edge case 3: n = 5, array = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
    Expected output: 3
    Explanation: The original mean is (1+2+3+4+5)/5 = 3. Possible pairs [i, j] that maintain the mean are [0, 1], [0, 2], and [1, 2].

# [extra code for edge case]
    We need extra code to handle the edge case where n = 3, as explained in the edge case analysis.
    def count_pairs(n, arr):
        if n == 3:
            return 0
        original_mean = sum(arr) / n
        count = 0
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(i+1, n):
                new_arr = arr[:i] + arr[i+1:j] + arr[j+1:]
                if sum(new_arr) / (n - 2) == original_mean:
                    count += 1
        return count

## Prompt 3:
[requirement]
Monocarp has an array a of n integers. The mean k is calculated as the sum of elements divided by the number of elements (sum/n). He wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still k. Calculate the number of pairs [i, j] (i < j) such that deleting the elements at these positions keeps the mean of (n - 2) elements equal to k.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

--------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
Example

Input

4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7

Output

6
0
2
3

[plan]
To solve this problem efficiently, we will use Python due to its powerful standard libraries and ability to handle large datasets. The approach involves calculating the mean of the array and then iterating through all possible pairs of indices to check if deleting the elements at these positions maintains the mean k. We will optimize the solution by avoiding unnecessary calculations and leveraging Python's efficient list operations.

examples:
Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.
